review.title: A bio-inspired algorithm for fuzzy user equilibrium problem by aid of Physarum Polycephalum
review.abstract: The user equilibrium in traffic assignment problem is based on the fact that travelers choose the minimum-cost path between every origin-destination pair and on the assumption that such a behavior will lead to an equilibrium of the traffic network. In this paper, we consider this problem when the traffic network links are fuzzy cost. Therefore, a Physarum-type algorithm is developed to unify the Physarum network and the traffic network for taking full of advantage of Physarum Polycephalum's adaptivity in network design to solve the user equilibrium problem. Eventually, some experiments are used to test the performance of this method. The results demonstrate that our approach is competitive when compared with other existing algorithms.

metadata.title: A bio-inspired algorithm for fuzzy user equilibrium problem by aid of Physarum Polycephalum

sections.text: ar Xiv: 140 6.21 28v1 [cs.AI] 9J unThe user equilibrium in traffic allocation is based on the fact that travellers choose the cost-effective route between each origin and destination pair, and on the assumption that such behaviour will lead to a balance of the transport network. In this paper, we look at this problem when the connections of the transport network are blurred costs. Therefore, a Physarum type algorithm is developed to unify the Physarum network and the transport network in order to take full advantage of the adaptability of Physarum Polycephalum in the network design to solve the user equilibrium problem. Finally, some experiments are used to test the performance of this method and the results show that our approach is competitive compared to other existing algorithms. Keywords: Blurred user equilibrium; traffic allocation; Physarum Polycephalum; adaptability.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to play by the rules they have had in the past, and they will be able to play by the rules they have had in the past, "he said in an interview with the New York Times.

sections.heading: 2. Preliminaries
sections.text: Some basic theories are presented in this section, including Physarum type algorithm for shortest path selection, user equilibrium in the transport network and basic concepts of Fuzzy set.2.1. Physarum type algorithm for shortest path selection. The shortest path selection process of Physarum polycephalum is based on the morphogenesis of the tube structure [18, 25]: on the one hand, the high rate of protoplasmic flow stimulates an increase in tube diameter, whereas pipes tend to decrease at a low flow rate. Therefore, the tube thickness adapts to the flow rate. On the other hand, the decrease in tube thickness in the organism is accelerated. Thus, the tube structure develops according to an equilibrium of these mutual antagonistic processes. Based on the observed phenomena of tube structure development, a simple Physarum polycephalum model is proposed, which is mathematically simplified and tractable.

sections.heading: 3. Proposed method
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1. Fuzzy user equilibrium
sections.text: It is a basic assumption that all travellers know the global information of the transport network (43). On this basis, anyone can make the decision that does not conflict with each other. However, in reality, due to some ambiguous events or local information, we can make the decision for the transport network in relation to the fluffy information of the transport network. In general, the fluffy information can be divided into three types: inaccurate travel costs, uncertain network topology and inaccurate travel demand. In this paper, we look at the user balance problem in relation to fluffy travel costs or fluffy user balances. According to Section 2.2, the fluffy user balance can be expressed as follows: min Z (w) = a (w) dw) dw, (20) s.t.

sections.heading: 4. Experimental results
sections.text: In this section we briefly illustrate the efficiency of the proposed algorithm by studying some sample networks.

sections.heading: 4.1. A test problem of Ramazani
sections.text: The first experiment involves a test problem introduced by Ramazani et al. [43]. It is based on a network of 4 nodes, 6 connections and a need for origin and destination, shown in Fig. 3. According to the known cost function presented by the US Bureau of Public Roads [44], the cost of connection a can be calculated as follows: ca (x) = ca0 (1 + α (xa ua) β) (28), where ca0 and u a are the cost of free flow and capacity of connection a, shown in Table 1. The parameters α and β are fixed values (common values are α = 0.15 and β = 4). Demand for origin and destination 1 − 4 is 700, namely q (1.4) = 700. The parameters αl and оr are assumed to be αl = αr = 0.2. The results of the allocation to the physarum algorithm (PA) are presented in Fig. 4 and Table 2. If we consider this equilibrium state, the cost of the TA can be presented as this 3 method of uncertainty.

sections.heading: 4.2. A test problem of Ghatee
sections.text: The second experiment concerns a test problem introduced by Ramazani et al. [3]. It is based on a network with 13 nodes, 15 links and five nodes, which is shown in Fig. 5. The capacity and cost of free flow of network connections are shown in Table 4. Assuming six (o, d) pairs {(1, 9), (1, 10), (1, 13), (5, 10), (5, 13)} as required {100, 200, 100, 150, 150, 150}, the results of the equilibrium flows and the equilibrium path data of each (o, d) pair are shown in Table 5 and Table 6 respectively.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we propose a Physarum network mode to solve the problem of fuzzy user equilibrium. We modify the Physarum type algorithm to build a relationship between the Physarum network and the traffic network so that they can multiply each other. In this way, an equilibrium state comes close to solving the fuzzy user equilibrium problem.

Recently, a large, single-celled amoeba-like organism, Physarum polycephalum, was found to be adaptively capable of solving many graph theoretical problems such as the shortest path found through a maze [17, 18, 19], path selection in networks [20, 21, 22], network design [23, 24].
